greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is taken to be the smallest positive integer not already present which is consistent with the condition "n is a member of the sequence if and only if a(n) is odd".
comment: The sequence obeys the rule: "The concatenation of a(n) and a(a(n)) is odd". Example: "1" and the 1st term, concatenated, is 11; "3" and the 3rd term, concatenated, is 35; "5" and the 5th term, concatenated, is 57; "2" and the 2nd term, concatenated, is 23; etc.
link: B. Cloitre, N. J. A. Sloane and M. J. Vandermast, Numerical analogues of Aronson's sequence, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 6 (2003), #03.2.2.
B. Cloitre, N. J. A. Sloane and M. J. Vandermast, Numerical analogues of Aronson's sequence, arXiv:math/0305308 [math.NT], 2003.
formula: All odd numbers occur; the only even numbers which occur are 2 and the multiples of 4 excluding 4 itself.
results.author: J. C. Lagarias and _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 11 2003
